ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I loved the readings for this class, and also got a good idea of how good ethnographic studies work.
I developed analytical and research skills.

I learned a lot about ethnography and reading them; I practiced discussing readings; I developed critical frameworks to think about the hemispheric Americas and their inhabitants, especially the young ones. I also was able to write an in-depth research paper which was very interesting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths- readings
Weaknesses- maybe less readings for a more fruitful class discussion.

I really like the discussion we have the class. Professor Ramos-Zayas is a great instructor. The only thing I would have wanted more is more guidance for the final paper. Because this was our only major assignment, it was hard to know what she wanted.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! AYRZ is such an amazing professor and I learned a lot.
I would, the readings were great and the class environment was great as well.

I took this course because I wanted to think more about ethnography and anthropology (about a topic I'm interested in, too), and Prof. Ramos-Zayas delivered that. I think if you're generally curious about the Americas and its young people, this is a great course to take. I ended up doing most of the readings and the response paper the day before but the paper forced me to engage with the materials in a way I thought was effective.

extras.title:
EDST 405 01/ER&M 410 01/AMST 455 01/WGSS 400 01/ANTH 470 01
        Youth Cultures in the Americas
